contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox UK place |country = England |static_image_name = St.Margaret's church, Quadring, Lincs. - geograph.org.uk - 84021.jpg |static_image_caption = St. Margaret's church, Quadring |latitude = 52.881105 |longitude = -0.180445 |label_position = top |official_name = Quadring |population = |shire_district = [[South Holland, Lincolnshire]] |shire_county = [[Lincolnshire]] |metropolitan_borough = | metropolitan_county = |region= East Midlands |constituency_westminster = [[South Holland and The Deepings (UK Parliament constituency)]] |post_town = Spalding |postcode_district = PE11 |postcode_area = PE |dial_code = 01775 |os_grid_reference = TF 22541 33066 | london_distance_mi= 97 | london_direction= S }} '''Quadring''' is a small village and [[civil parish]] in the [[South Holland, Lincolnshire|South Holland]] district of [[Lincolnshire]], England. It lies on the [[A152 road|A152]], {{convert|2|mi|km|1}} north-east from [[Gosberton]], and 2 miles south-east from [[Donington, Lincolnshire|Donington]]. The village includes the community of Barholme to its south-west. To the east of Quadring is Quadring Eaudike,<ref>[http://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/84476 Quadring Eaudike], geograph.org.uk; retrieved 25 June 2011</ref> and to the west is [[Quadring Fen]].<ref>[http://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/217006 Quadring High Fen], geograph.org.uk; retrieved 25 June 2011</ref> Nearby to the west is the [[Peterborough to Lincoln Line]]. The A152 (as Main Road within the village) transects Quadring and provides links to [[Spalding, Lincolnshire|Spalding]], [[Boston, Lincolnshire|Boston]], [[Donington, Lincolnshire|Donington]] and [[Gosberton]]. The village name is derived from the [[Old English]] "cwead+haefer+ingas" (Muddy settlement of Haefer),<ref>[http://www.genuki.org.uk/big/eng/LIN/Quadring/ Quadring], genuki.org.uk; retrieved 25 June 2011</ref> and is recorded in the ''[[Domesday Book]]'' as ''Quadheveringe'' and ''Quedhaveringe''.<ref>{{cite book| last =Williams | first =Ann | authorlink = | coauthors =Martin G. H | title =Domesday Book: A Complete Translation | publisher = Penguin| date = | location = | pages =899; 907; 964; 1390 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =978-0-14-143994-5 }}</ref> The Grade I [[listed building|listed]] village church,<ref>[http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-198221-church-of-st-margaret-quadring "Church of St Margaret, Quadring"], British Listed Buildings; retrieved 25 June 2011</ref> dedicated to [[Margaret the Virgin|St Margaret of Antioch]],<ref>[http://www.fenlander.info/quadring-st-margs.htm "History of St Margarets Parish Church"], fenlander.info; retrieved 25 June 2011</ref> lies north of, and separate from, the village. Mainly an example of [[English Gothic architecture#Perpendicular Gothic|Perpendicular]] architecture, it was rebuilt in 1872.<ref name=Cox>Cox, J. Charles (1916) ''Lincolnshire'' p. 245; Methuen & Co. Ltd</ref> Other listed buildings include a Grade II cottage, house, granary, coaching house, farm, and farm house.<ref>[http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/england/lincolnshire/quadring "Listed Buildings in Quadring, Lincolnshire, England"] British Listed Buildings; retrieved 25 June 2011</ref> ==Amenities== [[File:Post Office, Quadring, Lincs - geograph.org.uk - 351708.jpg|thumb|left|Village store and post office]] The local school is the Quadring Cowley and Brown's primary school. Previously Quadring had two [[public house]]s, a butcher, fishmonger, blacksmith, a slaughterhouse, and several pig farms. However today all that remains is a village store (that serves as a post office) and a public house, The White Hart, on Town Drove. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category inline|Quadring}} {{South Holland (district)}} {{Lincolnshire}} [[Category:Villages in Lincolnshire]] [[Category:Civil parishes in Lincolnshire]]
